Award.AbstractNarration:
CONTEXT
Energy investment and management decisions are increasingly facilitated and driven by information technology; these decisions have important impacts on the environmental, economic, and social characteristics of global energy systems--a collection of social-physical systems that weave together electric grids, fossil fuel production and utilization, regulation, development, markets, and diverse users and managers. Researchers from multiple disciplines are finding new ways of understanding and transforming energy systems as information technology and clean energy converge at an information-energy nexus.

INTELLECTUAL MERIT
This project will facilitate a new research community and build research infrastructure focused on understanding and shaping information-energy nexus research with a focus on electric power systems' critical role in human development and environmental performance.

The research community will bring together researchers who work in the developing and developed world. It will support a multidisciplinary and growing community of experts in energy and power systems analysis, engineering, social science approaches to energy development and public policy. The core community will be formed by colleagues at the University of California, Berkeley and Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory with partners that include energy practitioners working in low-income communities in the US and in rural Kenya.

The research infrastructure will focus on data collection and sensor design efforts that enable the exchange of perspectives. It will result in three sets of innovations that lead to research findings at the information-energy nexus: 1) new data sources and tools for household and firm energy analysis that leverage ubiquitous information technology, 2) improved data structures for linking interdisciplinary energy development datasets and models in time, space, and across other factors, and 3) targeted data analysis tools for addressing the critical issues of privacy, ownership, and the value of emerging energy datasets.

BROADER IMPACTS
Environmental and Social Impacts: Investments in infrastructure and modern loads are enabling factors for increasing the efficiency of the energy system, a key benefit for society and the most important broader impact of this work. Affordable and sustainable provision of energy services is the goal in both the US and Africa. Beyond environmental benefits, superefficient appliances and modern electricity infrastructure hold the promise to deliver more reliable and widely accessible energy services to global end-users, including the global poor.

Technological Impacts: This research will contribute broadly to understanding new architectures for organizing social-technical systems and specifically to innovation in clean energy technology and policy. Both data collection and data sharing challenges currently hinder these efforts.

Educational Impacts: The concepts in this research will be incorporated into undergraduate education in engineering and public policy, and in environmental studies, and will be shared with a diverse international network of educators and scholars working on issues of energy access.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was organized around two venues (low-income communities in Oakland, California, USA), and communiteis without electricty access in rural Kenya.  To build unique data sets on the role of informaiton technology to meet human needs, we developed Memoranda of Understanding with the two largest off-grid energy suppliers in Kenya, and both accessed and used unique proprietary data to explain broadly what was working, cost-effective, and serving consumer needs in the Kenyan off-grid energy market.

 We held widely attended workshops and local conferences on the role of information technology in supporting and selling off-grid energy products, in the process producing very widely read publications (see item 2, below), and well as addressing over 1,000 solar energy providers by playing a keynote role in the Secretary General Ban-ki Moon’s annual Sustainable Energy for All Conference.

 In the Oakland, USA context, we have: worked on a regular basis with the utility (PG&E) on new, open data protocols; we have enabled low-income energy providers (such as the award-winning [from the US EPA] Grid Alternatives, company), and we have presented our findings to the California Senate and Assembly, as well as to the U. S. Department of Energy.  Some of our depictions of the value of energy services (such as Figures 1a, 1b, and 2 in our Nature Climate Change paper from 2015) have become some of the most widely reproduced and used figures on energy access.

This project (specifically the Kammen, et al, 2014) paper was a direct invited input to the development of the Papal Encyclical on Climate change, and was quoted directly by the Pope in his comments in Bolivia (July 2015) on the opportunities to assist the poor in both energy and information provision.
